sections.title: Description
sections.paragraphs: Although the name applies to a group of snakes, it is often used to refer only to one species, in particular, the common or [[green anaconda]] (''Eunectes murinus''), which is the largest snake in the world by weight, and the second longest.

sections.title: Etymology
sections.paragraphs:
The South American names ''anacauchoa'' and ''anacaona'' were suggested in an account by [[Peter Martyr d'Anghiera]], but the idea of a South American origin was questioned by [[Henry Walter Bates]] who, in his travels in South America, failed to find any similar name in use. The word anaconda is derived from the name of a snake from Ceylon ([[Sri Lanka]]) that [[John Ray]] described in Latin in his ''Synopsis Methodica Animalium'' (1693) as ''serpens indicus bubalinus anacandaia zeylonibus, ides bubalorum aliorumque jumentorum membra conterens''.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://archive.org/stream/synopsismethodic00rayj#page/332/mode/1up |page=332 |year=1693 |author=Ray, John |title=Synopsis methodica animalium quadrupedum et serpentini generis |publisher=Impensis S. Smith & B. Walford |place=London}}</ref> Ray used a catalogue of snakes from the [[Rijksmuseum van Natuurlijke Historie|Leyden museum]] supplied by Dr. [[Tancred Robinson]], but the description of its habit was based on [[Andreas Cleyer]] who in 1684 described a gigantic snake that crushed large animals by coiling around their bodies and crushing their bones.<ref>{{cite book|first=Charles |last=Owen |year=1742| title=An essay towards a natural history of serpents |page=114|url=https://archive.org/stream/essaytowardsnat00owen#page/114/mode/2up/}}</ref> [[Henry Yule]] in his [[Hobson-Jobson]] notes that the word became more popular due to a piece of fiction published in 1768 in the Scots Magazine by a certain R. Edwin. Edwin described a '[[tiger]]' being crushed to death by an anaconda, when there actually never were any tigers in Sri Lanka.{{efn|In [[South Asia]]n languages like Hindi, the [[leopard]] and [[tiger]] may share the same name, that is ''Bágh'' ({{lang-hi|बाघ}}), and it is the former that occurs in Sri Lanka.<ref name="Pocock1930">{{cite journal |author=Pocock, R. I. |title=The Panthers and Ounces of Asia |journal=Journal of the Bombay Natural History Society |volume=34 |issue=2 |pages=197–336 |url=https://archive.org/stream/PocockMammalia1/pocock1#page/n249/mode/2up |year=1930}}</ref>}} Yule and [[Frank Wall (herpetologist)|Frank Wall]] noted that the snake was in fact a python and suggested a [[Tamil language|Tamil]] origin ''anai-kondra'' meaning elephant killer.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Wall |first=Frank |year=1921 |title=Ophidia Taprobanica or the Snakes of Ceylon. |publisher=Government Press |place=Ceylon |url=https://archive.org/stream/ophidiataprobani00wall#page/48/mode/1up/search/ |page=48}}</ref> A [[Sinhala language|Sinhalese]] origin was also suggested by Donald Ferguson who pointed out that the word ''Henakandaya'' (''hena'' lightning/large and ''kanda'' stem/trunk) was used in Sri Lanka for the small whip snake (''[[Ahaetulla pulverulenta]]'')<ref>{{cite journal |journal=Spolia Zeylanica |year=1904 |volume=1 |url=https://archive.org/stream/spoliazeylanica01nati#page/84/mode/1up/ |title=Some rare snakes of Ceylon|pages=81–89|author=Willey, A}}</ref> and somehow got misapplied to the python before myths were created.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Notes and Queries|volume=12|issue=294|year=1897|author=Ferguson, Donald |pages=123–124 |title=The derivation of "Anaconda" |url=https://archive.org/stream/s8notesqueries12londuoft#page/122/mode/1up|doi=10.1093/nq/s8-XII.294.123}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=A concise etymological dictionary of the English Language|last=Skeat|first=Walter W.| publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1882| page=16|url=https://archive.org/stream/conciseetymologi00skea#page/16/mode/1up}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url= https://archive.org/stream/hobsonjobsonagl02croogoog#page/n75/mode/1up|pages=24–25|title=Hobson-Jobson. |last1=Yule|first1=Henry|first2=A.C.|last2=Burnell|publisher=John Murray|place=London| year=1903}}</ref>

The name commonly used for the anaconda in Brazil is ''sucuri'', ''sucuriju'' or ''sucuriuba''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dicionário online de português: sucuriju|url=http://www.dicio.com.br/sucuriju/|accessdate=19 February 2014}}</ref>[[File:Anaconda Redpath museum.jpg|thumb|left|upright=2.5|Skeleton at the [[Redpath Museum]]]]
[[File:Anaconda and Squamata skeletons.jpg|thumb|14-foot anaconda skeleton (center) on display at the [[Museum of Osteology]] alongside other species for comparison.]]
{{-}}

In [[South Asia]]n languages like Hindi, the [[leopard]] and [[tiger]] may share the same name, that is ''Bágh'' ({{lang-hi|बाघ}}), and it is the former that occurs in Sri Lanka.<ref name="Pocock1930">{{cite journal |author=Pocock, R. sections.title: Species and other uses of the term "anaconda"
sections.paragraphs:
The term "anaconda" has been used to refer to:

[[File:Eunectes murinus - Flickr - Dick Culbert.jpg|thumb|upright=1.2|''Eunectes murinus'' in Colombia]]
* Any member of the genus ''[[Eunectes]]'', a group of large, aquatic snakes found in South America:
** ''[[Eunectes murinus]]'', the green anaconda – the largest species, found east of the Andes in Colombia, Venezuela, the Guianas, Ecuador, Peru, Bolivia, Brazil and [[Trinidad and Tobago]]
** ''[[Eunectes notaeus]]'', the yellow anaconda – a small species, found in eastern Bolivia, southern Brazil, Paraguay, and northeastern Argentina
** ''[[Eunectes deschauenseei]]'', the darkly-spotted anaconda – a rare species, found in northeastern Brazil and coastal French Guiana
** ''[[Eunectes beniensis]]'', the Bolivian anaconda – the most recently defined species, found in the Departments of Beni and Pando in [[Bolivia]]
* The term was previously applied imprecisely, indicating any large snake that [[constriction|constricts]] its prey,<ref name="COED">Oxford. 1991. The Compact Oxford English Dictionary. Second Edition. Clarendon Press, Oxford. {{ISBN|0-19-861258-3}}.</ref> though this usage is now archaic.
